message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome, which is caused by the loss of function of genes on chromosome 15. Symptoms can include poor muscle tone, almond-shaped eyes, downturned mouth, intellectual disability, and obesity. Hypogonadism is also commonly seen in Prader-Willi syndrome, which makes (C) the correct answer. Ataxia is not a common symptom, and hemihyperplasia and webbed neck are associated with different conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presenting symptoms are suggestive of Prader-Willi syndrome, which is characterized by hyperphagia, behavioral problems, and developmental delay. Hypogonadism is a common feature of this syndrome, so option (C) is the most likely additional finding. Ataxia and hemihyperplasia are not typically associated with Prader-Willi syndrome, and a webbed neck is a feature of Turner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome, including temper tantrums, food-seeking behavior, delayed cognitive development, and poor muscle tone. One of the hallmark features of Prader-Willi syndrome is hypogonadism, so (C) is the most likely additional finding. Ataxia, hemihyperplasia, and webbed neck are not typically associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.

The description of the patient suggests that he may have Prader-Willi syndrome, which is characterized by hyperphagia, developmental delay, and poor muscle tone. Among the additional findings listed, hypogonadism is commonly seen in patients with Prader-Willi syndrome. Ataxia and hemihyperplasia are not typical features of the syndrome, and webbed neck is associated with Turner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s physical examination findings suggest he may have Down syndrome. One common feature of Down syndrome is intellectual disability, which may affect the patient’s ability to count and name letters consistently. Poor muscle tone is also a characteristic feature. Of the options, only hypogonadism is a common complication of Down syndrome. Ataxia may be seen in other conditions such as cerebral palsy, but is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Hemihyperplasia and webbed neck are associated with other genetic disorders such as Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and Turner syndrome, respectively, but are not typically seen in Down syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has characteristic features of Prader-Willi syndrome, including temper tantrums, overeating, and poor muscle tone. Additionally, these patients commonly have cognitive impairment and delayed language development. Hypogonadism is also commonly seen in patients with Prader-Willi syndrome. Ataxia, hemihyperplasia, and webbed neck are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Prader-Willi syndrome. Hypogonadism is a common feature of this syndrome and may manifest as underdeveloped genitalia in boys or delayed onset of puberty in both males and females. Ataxia, hemihyperplasia, and webbed neck are not commonly associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.
